title: 66.46 : 1 Compound Planetary Gearbox for Robotic Arm

description.text:
Featured in these YouTube Videos!

  • Torque Test: https://youtu.be/YyoCF6DXfvI
  • Design and Calculations: https://youtu.be/1DNgqtoJMdk

Where's Everything Else???

  • This gearbox has an older, nearly identical twin, with the same outside form factor and different gear ratio, it can be found in the collection!
    https://www.thingiverse.com/Gear_Down_For_What/collections/robotic-arm
    In This Collection you will find:
    • All other related parts for this project
    • Future Updates to this Project
    • All User Submitted Remix's
    • Click that watch button to get notifications on future uploads!

Assembly

  • Assembly instructions can be found in the "Design & Calculations" Youtube Video above.
  • Aligning the gears with the marks is super important!
  • Placing the gears face up on a table, sort the planet gears in order (1-5) as shown in the main picture and video, insert sun gears, wrap the planets around the sun gears in the correct order, Snap Ring gear #1 on.
  • Align all gears with the marks as shown in the video, then put the rest of the ring gears on.
    You will need to close the gap in the rings before you spin this gearset or else it could skip teeth and get out of alignment, for this i have included the ring closures, that fits over all the rings
How it works

  • Ring Gears #1 & #3 will be at the same potential and Ring Gears #2 & (Optional #4) will be at the same potential

  • The use of Ring Gear #4, the 4 Module Planet Gears, and Sun Gear #4 is optional and used to increase the amount of torque this gearbox can transfer, as well as to decrease the amount of load on each gear, think of it like a door hinge.

Compatibility

  • This gear box is 100% compatible with the robotic arm!
  • This gear box can be used in any application that the 43.3:1 (from the "Robotic Arm" collection) gearbox is used in, because the outside of the rings gears, and the width of the ring gears are identical.
  • Do not mix and match gears between this gearbox and the 43.3:1.

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??

  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2wa7Eiz

  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, then I'll add them to my main collection so the whole community can share them! Thanks!

Gearing Information

  • Final Ratio 66.4615384615 : 1 (Thanks to ShapeShifter5 from Youtube!)
  • Planetary Gear Set #1 (Modules 1 and 3)
    • Teeth Sun: 13.00
    • Teeth Planets: 12.00
    • Teeth Ring: 37.00
  • Planetary Gear Set #2 (Modules 2 and 4)
    • Teeth Sun: 14.00
    • Teeth Planets: 11.00
    • Teeth Ring: 36.00
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

comments.text:
Great compact gearbox design. I have noticed that some of the planetary teeth have become mushroomed from the mismatched ratios. This binding or mushrooming occurs at the compound boundary from one planetary set to another, (that bit on the planetary gear where you performed the loft this gear to that gear operation). I have stuck each planetary gear in my drill and spun it slowly while taking a dremel with a diamond cutting blade at a 5 degree angle to cut a small v groove in the planetary teeth between all the sets. I cleaned up any burs in the teeth with a small wire brush. Reassembled the whole gearbox and now it rotates much smoother. However, there is axial and radial run-out that is inherent when not using any bearings.
It would be interesting to see any improvements that would utilize any form of bushing or bearings (even BB's) to stabilize the gearbox so that it could hold both rolls as a great compound and compact gearbox and as a joint bearing. Perhaps a sinusoidal design instead of the V-tooth herringbone pattern to reduce backlash when you scale down the planetary gears so they fit in the gearbox?

title: Ghost Body Front w/ Magnets - Original 6 Petal LED Tea Light

description.text:
Work in progress attempt at adding dieselkings magnet holes to the standard large ghost front body by BoldPrintShop. Holes appear to line up with the rear. Unsure about magnet hole depth. Feedback is appreciated as my printer is down at the moment. I can tweak as needed. Adjustment measurements in mm's is preferred. I only edited out the pin holes from BoldPrintShop original large front STL and inserted the magnet holes based on dieselking's sizing and position so it should be dimensionally the same as the originals.

Follow print settings suggested in other files. I personally have printed these in .15 and .20 mm layer heights but they look the same really. 20-30% infill but your preferences may vary.

Update 5/4/17: So finally got around to printing them and it looks like I pretty much nailed the positioning. So I am going to go ahead and set this as final. If anything the tolerances of your printer may make the hole a layer too shallow. I was able to fix this with a dremel carving bit. You may or may not have this issue. Please still leave a comment if you have any problems and I can try and tweak it for you.

title: Tabletop Universal Horizontal Filament Holder Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a fun way to mount my filament that that was different than your standard vertical spool holder. I also wanted it to be quick and easy to remove the spool when I am finished. This design is modeled off of the rotating tray you would find in a microwave.

The only supplemental items you would need are skateboard bearings. The ones I used have an 8mm center hole. All of the models are printed flat side down. I used supports on the arms. I have included both the arms with and without the triangles cut out. If you wish to print the arms with the cut outs I would recommend increasing the infill. Mine broke (35%) but it was easily repaired with cyanoacrylate glue. It is not essential that the arms are strong as they do not hold any of the filament load, they simply serve to hold the bearings upright and provide a reason for rotation to occur. All of the weight of the filament is distributed on the bearings.

I chose to use a couple of sticky vinyl bumpers to help center the spool on the carriage.

This is my first design and first upload. I loved it too much not to share.

title: Yet another thread library for OpenSCAD

description.text:
This is yet another OpenSCAD thread library, and it was more fun to write it than to find a library that did exactly what I wanted. It's designed to be fairly fast: it generates the whole thread polyhedron as a single piece.

Thread profile is completely flexible. You can specify a counterclockwise polygon of 2D points for the profile or you can use ISO thread profiles.

There are two modules exposed:
rawThread(profile, d=diameter, h=height[, lead=lead, $fn=segmentsPerRotation]): draw thread with specified profile; if lead is omitted, it is calculated from the profile
isoThread(d=majorDiameter, h=height, pitch=pitch[, angle=angle, internal=true/false, lead=lead, starts=starts, $fn=segmentsPerRotation]): draw metric ISO thread; default angle is 30; default is external thread (male); internal thread is designed for subtraction
If you want to use UTS measurements, you can omit pitch and instead do tpi=TPI, and then use hInch, dInch and leadInch instead of the metric versions. I haven't tested the UTS stuff yet.

For left-handed-thread, just mirror things.

If for some reason you want access to the points/faces of the thread polyhedron, these are available from the threadPoints() and extrusionFaces() functions.

The extrusionFaces(pointsPerSection, numSections) function is useful for more general extrusions than threads. It generates a set of triangular faces that can be fed into the faces= argument of polyhedron() for a tube-like non-self-intersecting extrusion with two end-caps and constant number of points on each cross-section. For a demo of how extrusionFaces() can be used to do that, see twisty.scad. There is also tubeFaces() which omits the end-caps, to be used for closed knots and the like.

Updates:

  • Dec 14, 2017: Fixed minor diameter calculation.
  • May 10, 2017: Add starts option for multi-start thread.
  • May 16, 2017: Fix tpi bug. Thank you to AlexeyBobkov.
  • May 31, 2017: Refactor functions, making for user-usable extrusionFaces() and tubeFaces()

comments.text:
Great library, thanks.
A small error: for inch threading, this line is not correct:
P = (tpi==undef) ? pitch : tpi;
Must be:
P = (tpi==undef) ? pitch : inch_to_mm(1/tpi);

My new sphere spinner with 1/2 inch ball bearings, and printable in two pieces. Print 2 halves with the flat side down. Place a ball in each pocket, place the 608 center bearing, put the second half on top with the countersunk holes offset from the opposite side, and use (4) 3mm by 10mm long screws on each side to screw it together. Printing in halves is best for multiple reasons. The balls fit in the pockets without stressing the material from pressing in, the bearing can be captive and wont slip, and the screws provide additional weight for spinning and look cool. Print the caps with the thumb socket on the table and the bearing side facing up.

comments.text: What type of M3 screws did you design this for? I tried every screw that I have (socket, flat) and the heads stick out (they don't fit inside the holes). Also, the lip for the bearing allows for too much play - if pressed with a vise, it goes in too deep, past the 3.5mm.

Hola a todos!!"

Hoy les mostramos 3 tipos de ruedas locas o Caster Wheel (en inglés) que pueden usar en sus proyectos de robótica. Las hemos diseñado y usado en nuestras creaciones con el fin de permitirnos giros libres a partir de movimientos a dos motores. Esperamos que las pruebes. E igualmente dejamos los archivos en formato SLDPRT (Solidworks) para que los modifiques de acuerdoa tú requerimiento.

Cualquier comentario es bienvenido.

No seas un simle mortal!

title: RileyLink ToughCase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case for the RileyLink. It includes three components:

  1. Top of RileyLink Case - RileyLink_Case_-_Top_r10.STL (3D printed)
  2. Bottom of RileyLink Case - RileyLink_Case_-_Bottom_r10.STL (3D printed)
  3. Screw to fasten them together - Flat Head M2 X 0.4 mm pitch 6mm long (hardware)

Purchase:

This case is available on https://getrileylink.org/product/rltoughcase/ for $37 with an expected first ship date of June 1, 2017. The shipment will include both pieces of the ToughCase, the screw and the key ring.

Design goals:

  • 3D printed clasps are fragile and break, resulting in cases that are held together with tape. We wanted to eliminate this outcome.
    • We created a connection point between the two 3D printed parts that allows a small screw to fasten them together.
  • We wanted to optimize for overall durability. Should a heavy object fall on my RileyLink (yes, this happened to me), we wanted it well protected.
    • We increased wall thickness to 2mm.
    • Instead of using a front/back 50:50 design like the original RileyLink case, we're using top/bottom 25:75 design. The increased substance of one piece (the bottom) yields a more sturdy structure.
  • If we shake the RileyLink case, we want the internals secure so they don't move around.
    • We gave each component of the RileyLink, the PCB and the battery, its own dedicated, specifically sized slot. It's intentionally a tight fit.
  • We wanted to keep the size of this case as close to the size of the original RileyLink case as possible.
    • See comparison pics below.
  • We wanted to align mini-USB port on the PCB to its opening on the case precisely, so inserting a mini-USB charger is easy.
  • We wanted to support physical add-ons like car keys or a Tile bluetooth locator.
    • We added a hole for a key ring.

Range:

We've had several inquiries about the range of the RileyLink inside a ToughCase, so we conducted a test. 

SUMMARY: 
- Test conducted on a golf course.
- Connection up to 30 meters (100 feet) was consistently successful. (3 of 3 successful)
- After 30 meters (100 feet), connection reliability began to degrade. (3 of 6 successful)
- Farthest range with successful connection demonstrated was 52 meters (171 feet).
EQUIPMENT:

(1) RileyLink in ToughCase (printed from Nylon)
(1) iPhone running LoopApp
(1) Medtronic 723 pump running VER 2.4A
(2) people
PROCEDURE:

The individual holding the RileyLink in ToughCase and iPhone stands still, while the individual holding the Pump moves away to a measured distance. 

At each new distance:
1. On iPhone, run LoopApp > Settings > Rileylink > Tune
2. See if it succeeds or fails
3. Screenshot the Tune results (success or failure)
4. Measure the distance between the two people (using AtoB iPhone app in "as a crow flies" mode)
RESULTS:

Test Sequence 1
- 25 meters (82 feet) | 1 test | result: success
- 39 meters (128 feet) | 1 test | result: success
- 52 meters (171 feet) | 1 test | result: success (photos included below)

Test Sequence 2
- 28 meters (92 feet) | 2 tests | successful: 2, failing: 0
- 34 meters (112 feet) | 2 tests | successful: 1, failing: 1
- 42 meters (138 feet) | 2 tests | successful: 0, failing: 2
LIMITATIONS:

- We wanted to isolate this range analysis test from variables that may cause interference (e.g., walls, wireless devices, etc), so we conducted this test on a golf course. 
- This test was conducted with one RileyLink in one ToughCase communicating with one pump. We did not attempt to replicate the results with multiple sets of hardware.

Instructions for Printing on Fictiv:

I had my case printed and shipped on fictiv.com with great results. My total cost was $79.49, including tax and shipping. It took five business days. (There's another option for 3 business days.)

  • Go to www.fictiv.com
  • Create your account
  • Select files: Upload .STL files
    • RileyLink_Case_-_Top_r10.STL
    • RileyLink_Case_-_Bottom_r10.STL
  • Process and Material
    • Process: 3D Printing
    • Material: Nylon
  • Color and Finish
    • Color: White or Black (might white one got dirty fast)
    • Finish: As printed
  • Production speed
    • 3 days or 5 days (impacts price)
  • Price
    • Mine was about $30 per piece, +shipping, totaling $79.49.

Purchase the Screw:

  • Flat Head M2 X 0.4 mm pitch 6mm long You only need one. You can probably get it from your local hardware store, or here's a link to an Amazon 10-pack.

Optional Customization:

  • If you're comfortable with 3D modeling software, you can add your own custom fonts and graphics. Use the .IGS files. (The .STL are just for printing as is.)
  • As you'll see in the photos, I added orcas to the sides. I also added my name and phone number to the front (not pictured).
  • The 3D files posted on Thingiverse are generic. We left in the text on top that says "Medical Device", but the orcas and my contact info are gone.

Makers:

  • This case was a collaboration between Brandon Arbiter (T1D since 2011, OpenAPS since 2015, Loop since 2016) and Jason Lichtman, professional product design engineer Fictiv | LinkedIn.

Final product, with Tile attached via key ring. - Side view PCB and battery inserted - side view PCB and battery inserted - angle view PCB and battery inserted - angle view PCB and battery inserted - top view Case closed - side view Case closed - angled view Original RileyLink case left, new case right. For size comparison - side view. Original RileyLink case left, new case right. For size comparison - back view. Original RileyLink case on top, new case on bottom. For size comparison - stack view. Original RileyLink left, new case right. For size comparison - bottom view. Longest successful tune - 52 meters (171 feet). Photo of person holding Pump taken by person holding iPhone and RileyLink ToughCase immediately after test. Longest successful tune - 52 meters (171 feet). Screenshot of distance measured by AtoB app.

comments.text: Hi Jace1969 what are your print settings ? Infill and support mainly thanks
comments.author: 3dprinting117

comments.text:
For my Wanhao, I found the sweet spot for my machine with a 0.6 nozzel at 0.2 layer, (top - bottom & outter layer shells all 3) infill layer 20%
100% extrusion width. Infil support 70% and dense infil supoort 60% becuase I have had better results with a better quality infill support ; )
I use home made ABS so I dont have to worry about the amount of plastic I waste or use. Hot end is worked well at 240c and the bed is at 90c with a small amount of ABS slurry to bond the first layer to eliminate warping is a must and an enclosure with its ambient temperature of around 50c + Good luck Cheers Jace ; )

author: femoral

title: Dreadnought Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Dreadnought is an all enclosed Fidget Spinner. It has the option of an 11mm or 14mm bearing. These are smaller bearings than the standard spinner types. The bearing size must be 5mm thick with a 5mm inner bore. The other diameter can be either 11mm or 14mm. Just look at the .STL files for the correct pair.

The weights are standard M8 nuts. AMERICANS... you can just search that online for the imperial conversion size.

Because the bearings are smaller than the typical 608 bearings they won't spin for as long. This is meant to be an all enclosed spinner that just looks really amazing!

Materials:
1-Printed Parts
2-5mmx11mmx5mm Bearing ~OR~ 5mmX14mmX5mm Bearing
3-M8 Nut (or Imperial Equivalent)
4-Glue (Super Glue works well)
5-Clamps

Instructions:
1-Print your parts
2-Place nuts and bearing in one side of the spinner
3-Glue (super glue works well) one side of the spinner
4-Clamp them together and let dry. Use multiple clamps with one on the center where the bearing is and two more for each side.
5-Put some glue on the small end of one of the bearing handles.
6-Place bearing handles together into the the center of the spinner. Be careful not to get glue on the bearing.
7-Clamp the handles together to that they are straight, then let dry.

author: sabharish

print_settings.Notes:: 0.2mm layers

description.text:
This is a tripod mount ring for large lenses. This helps you balance your camera and lens on a tripod or monopod. It's been tested on Canon lenses, 70-200mm (ring A) and 70-300mm (ring C).

It's customizable, with presets available for all Canon lenses and some Nikon lenses. Premade STL files are available for all known Canon and Nikon mount rings in the download section. Or, you can use Customizer to tweak things for your application.

I've included a knob designed to hold a 1/4" nut. It was generated using wstein's Ultimate Nut Knob Generator. Use that script if you want more control over the knob.

Manufactured metal and ABS mount rings go for as little as $15 on Amazon or Aliexpress if you'd rather have something sturdier. OEM models are quite a bit more expensive. My prints feel pretty sturdy, but the usual risks of 3D print failure apply. USE THIS MODEL AT YOUR OWN RISK.

Best uses for this:

  • You're borrowing a lens and don't want to buy a mount ring
  • You need a mount ring and can't get one in time for your shoot
  • You've got some obscure lens for which a mount ring isn't commercially available
  • You're trying to hard-mount a tube to a tripod and need a convenient attachment

Please leave comments! Or upload a "Make"; I'd love to see your copy in action.

I don't recommend using PLA. In my limited tests, even high-impact or temperature-resistant "dishwasher safe" PLA caused the clamp to loosen over time as the plastic stretched. PET (t-glase or PETG), ABS, nylon, and other materials with good layer adhesion that won't deform in a hot car should work well. The knob is low-stress and can be printed in any material.

The model is oriented for printing. Print it on its back so the print grain runs around the ring for strength.

My settings (Deltaprintr):

  • 0.2mm layers
  • 1.2mm walls (3 shells)
  • 1.0mm top/bottom surface thickness
  • 35% infill
  • No supports
  • Whatever speed gives good layer adhesion for your material

Hardware

Any hardware store should carry the metal parts you need. I recommend using a 1/4" nut & bolt for the clamp, but you could go smaller.

  • (1) 1/4-20 x 1.5" bolt (preferably stainless) (or 6mm x 40mm, preferably coarse thread)
  • (1) 1/4-20 nut (preferably stainless) (or 6mm)
  • (1) 1/4-20 T-nut (standard tripod screw size)

NOTE: I've only tested T-nuts for the tripod mount. I haven't tested threaded inserts, hex nuts, or screwing into the plastic.

The script has presets for using a threaded insert or a regular hex nut for the tripod mount. If at all possible, you'll get the sturdiest mount from a T-nut or perhaps a threaded insert. A hex nut may tear out of the plastic, and I strongly do not recommend screwing the tripod screw directly into the plastic. If you must, I've read that you should print with wall thickness equal to the bolt's diameter, which is 6.35mm for 1/4".

If the knob is too tight to sink a nut into, try dipping the lower part in boiling water for about 10 seconds, screw the nut onto a few threads of a bolt, and use the bolt to press the nut into the warm plastic.

Read the excellent 3DHubs documentation on using threaded fasteners with 3D prints.

Assembly

If you're using a T-nut or a push-fit threaded insert, I recommend pushing them into the plastic using a soldering iron that heats the insert so that it melts into the plastic. Now's a good time to review that 3DHubs tutorial.

Add the clamp bolt and nut by inserting the bolt from the side of the clamp with the hex-shaped recess. Add the nut, but don't tighten it down until you've installed the ring on the lens.

Install the ring on your lens with the foot pointing toward the front of the lens. You may want to add a piece of rubber or felt between the ring and the lens to give the ring more grip or allow the lens to rotate easier.

Now's a good time to mount everything on a tripod and really twist and torque the whole thing to make sure it's not going to flex too much or give out. Better to find problems while sitting on a soft cushiony couch than while standing on a rocky cliff.

A friend rented a long lens to cover a sporting event, but didn't have a tripod mount ring to go with it. I figured they looked easy enough to design, so I knocked something together in OpenSCAD. It took me about ten revisions to get to the model here.

Early revisions didn't have enough finger clearance to comfortably use the lens focus/zoom rings. Middle versions had clamps with too little adjustment and which deformed under tension. The final design is meant to resist deformation, but it really needs to be printed in a material that's less likely to deform.

Intermediate versions with minor variations. Bottom right is the final version of a Canon C ring for a 70-300mm L IS lens, printed in black t-glase. Intermediate versions with minor variations. Bottom right is the final version of a Canon C ring for a 70-300mm L IS lens, printed in black t-glase.

comments.text: Incredible design, great use of vase printing.  I was amazed that a part this large could be printed in just over four hours.  I sliced this using Simplify3D and printed it on my Monoprice Select Mini V2 using PLA filament.  My hot end was at 205C and my heated bed was at 60C.  It came out pretty nice-the only issue was that the top solid layers did fell in a little due to the 0% infill that comes with vase mode.  So the top layer doesn't look great, but the rest is pretty much perfect.

author: Sjunior

print_settings.Notes:: Suggested Print Settings: ABS. Use a brim of 5-10mm to help minimise warping. No Support material is required. Print with arms in vertical position, ie. fan mount facing heat bed. Slower speed is recommended, I used about 30mm/s. Test printed in Silc3r & Cura, had better results with Slic3r. You may get a "Not Manifold" warning in your slicer program, but the g-code will still be produced without requiring "repair". Design resolution is 0.1mm, however, suggested print settings are: 0.35 first layer, 0.2mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle.

title: BW Cooling Fan Duct & Adapter for E0 spacer & BLTouch

description.text:
This is a parts cooler for a Tevo Black Widow with E3D-V6 using a spacer to centralise the extruder and provide stepper motor clearance on right hand side frame, (gaining more print space). The "Black Widow Extruder Mount" (spacer) designed by PhantomGT, Nov 9, 2016 (thank you) is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1880081

This 'spacer' also allows you to mount the BLTouch directly behind the extruder.
If you have used one of the above spacers, you may use my parts cooler & adapter which provides clearance for the BLTouch and enough reach for several air ducts to cover the work piece.

This is a new design, which allows air to cover a wide area of the work piece and is small enough to use on the stock extruder and heat block.

The cooler is attached to the adjustable mount using a single M3 x 10mm screw.
The adjustable mount is attached to the hole on the bottom left hand side of the X-axis mounting plate using an M4 x 16mm.

Note: the M3 x 10mm cooler to mount screw-head must fit inside the provided recess to clear the circuit wiring on the back of the BLTouch.

The 40 x 40mm fan is attached using M3 screws. Bolt pattern 32 x 32mm
Fan & Adapter holes should be cleaned/drilled with a 7/64 (2.8mm) drill allowing the screws to thread into the cooler duct directly (ie. no nuts required).

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

20%

author: SportSedan

description.text:
This is a semi automatic Z-probe setup for CR-10.

The idea is that you mount the probe, measure a grid of points in your bed, use this information to adjust your leveling screws and repeat. When you are satisfied with the bed leveling , perform a final measurement, save the matrix to the EEPROM as the final ABL Bilinear Matrix and unmount the probe.

This has some assumptions:
1) You dont have the original cooling system metal cage (you moved to fang or other). The mount will use their original screws.
2) You want to use a microswitch style Bed proving. The prove is designed for Microswitch
3) You changed your Firmware accordingly to allow ABL and Zprobing. (dont use safe homing). CR-10 marling 1.0 does not have bed leveling nor zprobing enabled. you would need to download and configure last version of Marlin.

The mount has 2 screws plus a rail with a registration hole for accurate and repeatable probe attachment. all the screws are M3, the registration nut is M3 too.

The probe is designed to be printed without supports and be rigid and light as possible. the tip of the probe has room for a standard microswitch. Orient it the closest to the bed. There are 2 holes for better cable management. CR-10 uses NC z-endstop, this means the circuit is closed always and when the z-endstop is triggered the circuit is open. To wire the microswitch of the probe you need to put in the middle of any of both z-enstops cables. Its easy to keep stock by crafting the a simple 2 wire cable with and a female connector (2.54 3p Xh) on each side.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The mount requires support.
The probe is desinged to be printed support less.
You can print it in 0.1 or 0.2.

Onshape

Feel free to clone-modify/remix

https://cad.onshape.com/.../e/135bae1833d30bf33dd48cf6

description.text:
A straight forward case for the Raspberry Pi 2 or 3.

** Updated base to v3, tweaked the aperture tolerances to make for an easier fit and removed the central pillar separating the USB bays for same.

I designed this primarily to take my Octoprint Pi, as I want to be able to mount this onto the enclosure I'm building for my printer I've included 4 countersunk fastening holes. I've also included open access to the SD card so that swapping that out doesn't necessarily need the lid taken off or the Pi removed. I've printed it in ABS (photos to follow), it's a bit of a tight fit to get the Pi in place but it does fit with gentle persuasion.

Still clinging on to 123D Design as my Cad package of choice, I'll have to convert to Fusion at some point but 123D still works and does everything I need for this sort of design.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

50% for rigidity when printing

Notes:

I tried printing the base without supports and whilst it printed there were a couple of fit issues caused by sagging bridge parts so best to go with support for all the cutouts.

I upped the infill to try and keep it from warping when using ABS, doesn't need that level from a use point of view so if you know that warping isn't an issue for you then you could reduce that.

author: Ganesh37

print_settings.Notes:: Don't get bothered when the surface above the removed support structure is not perfect, as long as the parts are fitting it will probably working.

description.text:
Based on the great design of chopmeisters H3-Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27626) - Thanks for your great work!! - i modified the design.

If you design a holder it would probably suit for all printers which allow bowden extruders.
At the moment: Ultimaker and Prusa i3 MK2 (tested) and .

Modifications:

  • Herringbone gear
  • 5mm axle on big gear (instead of 8mm)
  • extruder gear for 5mm axle
  • fitting for Bowden connection which is easily removeable for Filament insertion (in case it's needed)
  • Locking adjusted and additional hole added - in case the locking is not working well you have the possibility to hold it with a M3 screw (or allen key or whatelse)
  • using a guide bearing for better filament adjusting at the extruder drive gear

  • Less parts to mount, but less flexibility concerning the Bowden connection and printing with support required (you can't get it all ;-) ).

    The Tension knob (Tension_Knob.STL) and the Ultimaker mount (UM_mount.STL) have to be used from chompeisters H3-extruder (see link above).

At the moment the design is working well on a Prusa i3 MK2, hopefully it will get working well on UMO+ soon when the modification to dual extrusion is finished.

Parts needed:
1 x grooved bearing, similar to 624ZZ - D13mm, d4mm T4mm (T5mm will also work if you use a file ;-) ).
1x spring (at least it should fit for M4)
1x extruder drive gear
Ii used these parts of the "anycubic MK8 extruders",
2 x berarings 625ZZ
2 x screw M3x25
2x screw M3x20 (for printer-mounting adapter)
3x screw M3x10 and washers (motor fixing)
6x nut M3
2x countersunk screw M3x6 or M3 grub screw (for the small gear)
2x washers for M4
1x screw M4x20 or M4x25 (the longer one if you use a locking nut)
2x nut M4 (maybe one of these a locking nut for the guide bearing)
1x screw M4x35-40 or (as i did) threaded rod M4 L=45mm and two nuts M4 (for the Tension knob)
4x nut M5 DIN934 - ISO4032 is thicker!! (3 for the herringbone gear and one for locking it)
1x axle 5mm, L=45mm (or longer), cut a thread M5 on the length min. 15mm (for mounting the big gear wheel).
1x fitting: i used a Metalwork R1 straight cylindrical brass fitting. G1/8 and 4mm for 1.75mm bowden (use Halterung_Verschraubung_d4_G1_8_V2_H3+Extruder.stl) or G1/4 and 6mm (use Halterung_Verschraubung_d6_G1_4_H3+Extruder.stl).
I can't tell you which other fittings will work, i would say max. G1/4 and you need a diameter above the thread for clamping. Maybe you have design a fitting-holder for yourself.

Washers and small parts as you need it ;-) I used some for the dictance of the big gear wheel to the body. You can also print a sleeve, whatever you want.

And of course a Motor NEMA17 and a printer to build up gg
Maybe you have to change the firmware - rotation of the extruder motor. At least i had to do it at Prusa i3MK2 changing from a direct drive to a geard extruder.

On Prusa i3MK2 i also used a bowden to guide the filament from the roll to the extruder. Otherwise it will get jammed somwhere. This bowden is loose, the stiffness of the bowden is enough for guiding.

Good luck ;-)

Update 2017-07-13:
V2 available ;-) (Sorry for the looong delay).
Changes:
Gears: Small gears widened to avoid scratching of the teeth (big weel) on the side. Added chamfer on big gear teeth, adjusted dimension for easier assembly of the nuts.
Body and all other parts: Adjusted to fit better for 2.85mm filament. V1 worked but filament change/insertion was VERY unpleasant. Should be better now, maybe still not perfect. Additionally small (nearly not mentionable) improvements done.
Coordinate System changed on some parts, so most of the parts should be correctly orientated for printing.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed the parts with ABS.

Be carefully when adjusting the parts for print: on some you see chamfers or fillets on the UPPER side (see picture). Do not print the parts as shown in thingiverse preview (some may work, some not).

I printed the parts with Cura 2.5Beta and a Prusa i3MK2 and 0.5mm nozzle (i'm sure other nozzles will do it too, maybe reduce the printing speed):
ABS, Print speed 60mm/s, BedTemp 110°C, FanSpeed 30%.

I printed the gears with 100% infill (solid). At least this is no disatvantage concerning reliability (especially wear).

Don't get bothered when the surface above the removed support structure is not perfect, as long as the parts are fitting it will probably working.

Designing History

Built up the desiged H3-extruder from chopmeister. When building up some thoughts for modifications came up - mostly because of the parts i had here an didn't want to order (f.eks. 1 screw and 1 bearing), also some problems - f.eks. the locking didn't work so i had to use a velcro and added a hole later with an allen key through ist ;-)
Once i orderd some DIY extruders from anycubic (see in a search engine) and i like these extruder drive gears. Also the guiding bearings are used from them.

As i had really a lot of problems with my Prusa i3 MK2 i tried to change the extruder to a bowden extruder. I have also an Ultimaker Original + (but not placed at my home) and (after some beginning problems and modifications) it is running great. I think the most important thing for reliability is the extruder, and UMO+ has a great working extruder. So i ended up playing with chopmeisters H3 design. Since i changed the extruder nearly all problems vanished ;-)))
Now i have to play with the settings to get rid of the stringing ;-)

comments.text:
As the Version 1 is not very convenient for 3mm filament a new Version (V2) will come soon. It works, but due to the holes for the filament is too tight near the extruder gear it is not possible to push the filament but you have to turn the wheel for quite a long time...
Also the clearances will be adjusted for easier mounting - f.eks. putting in the nuts was quite hard sometimes.
comments.author: the_mechanical

comments.text: I uploaded the wrong holder for the G1/8 - d4 fitting (1.75mm bowden), SORRY, it is corrected now (Halterung_Verschraubung_d4_G1_8_V2_H3+Extruder.stl)

When tinkering with electronics or mechanical projects you need these for exampe to mount your PCB securely in its case. Of course you have tons of them laying around from scrapped machinery but you need four similar ones and you can only find three! Or you cannot find the right size at all. (Recognizable?)
This is not excactly an advanced design but with the power of Customizer you can stop searching through your scrap pile and easily make your distance holders in the right size and colour.
Throw as many on your build plate as you need and print them all at once.
For small sizes, using a brim is definitely recommended.

description.text:
This is a remix v5 of the case designed by freshwaterfish1, with a voronoi pattern set into the back of the case. The dimensions of the case have not changed, so it will be a snug fit like his original design.

I designed this for print with MJF or SLS, I'm not sure how this will come out in FDM with the narrow channels. If you are attempting in FDM maybe try VoronoiCase.stl instead of VoronoiCase_R2.stl, it has a flat bottom and may adhere better to the bed.

description.text:
Modular Lampshade is a shade that is made from small pieces that fit together and make up a 12 sided cylinder. Modular Lampshade is for tabletop usage.

The idea is to play with different colors. Maybe print the shade with three colors? Or four or six. In my example print I made it with two colors: Yellow and white. Yellow color for calming light. But who is to say that you couldn't print it with more?

Print details:

WALL.stl objects were printed with Wall Count 1, but in hindsight I suggest you put it 2-3, so the thickness will soften the light some more.

WALLWITHHOLE.stl is printed only once per shade. This is the piece where cord can go through.

BOTTOM.stl is a long print. I changed the thickness of it after printing to match TOP piece thickness, so the shade looks more polished. Dimensions are made with standard E27 light bulb. Please use only LED based bulbs for this! They won't warm up so much.

TOP.stl will tie the pieces together when you have reached the height that you are reaching for. Shade will become very sturdy after installing this. I suggest a height at least four layers of WALL objects.

Tip for assembly: Start with BOTTOM and WALLWITHHOLE and continue assembly one by one with WALL pieces. Don't be afraid to use rubberhammer or such if the holes feel too tight (I used hammer only once during assembly). I used a file and a blade post-printing for the joints. They had some inaccuracies and leftover filament.

Tip for printing: I printed WALL objects usually after some other prints if nozzle was the right size (0.6). WALL is quite fast print which doesn't need massive post-printing processing, so the shade came together piece by pieces slowly. If there is small errors in WALL objects, just let them be. Light will make them disappear and maybe it brings some "personality" to the shade. Remember that only the front of the WALL object will show in the final shade. Joints are hidden.

Anyway. Play with the colors! and maybe leave some holes to the assembly if you want. The joints should hold.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Use file and small blade in places where there are some inaccuracies or leftover filament.

description.text:
A 3 dimensional, 2 color title bar to give your Prusa i3 that professional look!  
I printed the outset in green and the inset in white. This color combination looks great, as well as lots of other combinations.   
I included the full logos for the inset and outset, but those won't likely fit on any print bed. So, I also included broken up versions that you can arrange on the bed to fit better.

This model was printed on a Prusa i3--Obviously! .23 layer height
2 perimeters
Honeycomb infill
1 bottom layer, 3 top layers (to give really clean top)
Outset printed in green, inset in white---looks really cool Print this out for your i3 and give your printer some character!

description.text:
• Goal
    I originally started this project because I wanted to understand how a quadcopter operates. As the project moved forward, it became more and more important for me to share what I learned. So, I decided to build a new open source quadcopter using Elixir, the project’s goal is the be educational, everyone that reads the code should understand the basics of how a quadcopter works.

  • Material:

    • M3 srews and nuts
    • 16mm and 8mm carbon tubes
    • PLA
    • Flex PLA

  • Links

    • Github: Elicopter on Github
  • Contact

Don't hesitate to reach me if you have any questions at [email protected]

title: Luzbot Mini Tool Holder (Clam Knife, Tweezer)

description.text:
Lulzbot Mini is a great printer period. It even comes with a lot of tools. Of the tool kit, I use the Clam Knife the most and probably the Tweezer second. I wanted to find a way to keep them organized as part of my printing workstation so I came up with a simple design. Providing two sizes, small one for just the clam knife (aka Parts removal knife) and another larger one for both the knife and tweezer.

Note: The gap I designed should have some tension to keep itself in place, but for added mounting security, I recommend using some thin double sided tape (as seen in one of the pictures I took) to help wedging it in nice and tight against the frame.

title: Small League of Legends Icon Hand Spinner with Quarter weights Customizable

description.text:
I figured I would join the fad. I didn't want to waste bearings as weights on this spinner. Instead, I chose to use 6, US $0.25 coins. The coins and the bearing press fit in. I have used a little cyanoacrylate glue to keep the coins in place. The endcaps in the main file are modeled after the desktop icon for one of my favorite games. I have included a blank cap that I glue onto the twist in axils post production for your customization. (It is nothing more than at cylinder with an 11.5mm radius and 2mm height.)

Thank you to berky93 and 2ROBOTGUY for those twist in axils centers for the bearing. I love them!

I haven't seen too many spinners in person but I feel like this one is on the smaller side, about 45mm from the center to the ends of each arm. I have played with it discreetly in my coat pocket on numerous occasions.

Have fun customizing the caps to personalize them for you. I just made one for my bosses daughter with her initials on it.

author: majid62

description.text:
Poppy Ergo Jr

Poppy Ergo Jr robot is a small and low cost 6-degree-of-freedom robot arm.

It works with Dynamixel XL-320 motors, and a Raspberry Pi for control.
It comes with three tools (end effector):

  • a lampshade
  • a grasper
  • a pen holder

You can control the robot with Python (from a Jupyter notebook interface) or via Snap, a visual programming language similar to Scratch.

You can buy all pieces by yourself (BOM link), or buy robot without printed parts on one of Poppy distributors.

Assembly Guide

A full assembly guide is available on the online Poppy documentation.

About Poppy Project

Poppy is an interdisciplinary platform gathering beginners and experts, scientists, educators, developers and artists, that all share a vision: robots are powerful tools to learn and be creative.
The Poppy community develops robotic creations that are easy to build, customise, deploy, and share.

  • GitHub repository (software and hardware)

  • Community forum to share things, ideas or ask help

title: Shield/ Hydra coin - remix with support + fridge magnet version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of a coin that has a S.H.I.E.L.D. logo on one side and Hydra logo on the other.

  • The mesh was cleaned up a bit.
  • Scaled the whole coin up to around 3cm diameter.
  • I've thickened the outer circle.
  • Made the Hydra logo bigger, so more details can come out fine.
  • Made a version with custom support bars to make it more stable. I still recommend using generated support too with both versions.

Update #2: Uploaded a fridge magnet version of the coin.

It needs a 8x1mm neodymium magnet to be inserted in it. The insertion is done during printing, so either you are lucky and your software and printer supports pausing at a specific height (and moving away the head), or you hack the g-code manually to do this.
The magned is inserted while the print is paused, then it can be resumed and the magned is sealed inside.

I did the g-code hack version. I'd write a how-to, but when I started it... well it turned out that there are too many differences between firmwares/hardwares/slicers/host-softwares, plus the combination of these. You really need to know what you are doing if you want to do the g-code hack.
In short: Find the point in the g-code where the pause should be inserted, move the head away with "G0" instructions (you can do an extra retract here). I did it by moving the head up, to the back, then down to 0 in Z, so the print-bed prevents oozing (as seen on the picture). Paused the print there with "M25" (Marlin firmware doesn't support "M226"), inserted the magnet, then pressed "resume" on the LCD. My remaining additional code then raised the head back up, forward, and the printing went on from there.

Update #1: Made the sides of the coin totally flat, so it can now be printed on its face if you want to.

I suggest printing it with generated support and also brim. Two prints were ruined halfway before I've added the manual supports and brim, then it is constantly good.
Also, printing it on lower speed has better results with PLA, because it has time to cool down. Also I recomment using 90-100% cooling.

The pictures were taken from a coin with supports, no post-processing done yet. It was made a bit too fast, the next coin is set to lower speed so all details will come out nice.

Note: The logos are from MARVEL's "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D." series. So no commercial use allowed, print it for fun!

Printer:

Easy3DMaker - modded

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Nozzle: 0.5mm

I highly recommend this exact posture, because this gives you the most detail. Harder to print than if it would lay flat, but then the Hydra logo would come out bad.

Unless you have a very fine nozzle with a diameter which can bring out all the small details of the Hydra logo even if printed flat.
And it is also an option to scale up the model.
Of course it needs sanding/polishing, because of the stepping effect coming out badly in this particular pose.

description.text:
2nd Place Trophy for our Fantasy Football league. Modeled after the Lamar Hunt/George Halas trophy, (the AFC/NFC Champions get). The loser of the Superbowl gets one of these so I figured it would be an appropriate "silver medal" to design off of.

Named after a great man, (Papa Al Sauro), who loved Hawaii, this trophy was a beast to get right, but came out pretty well, all things considered. A little deformation on the bottom of the vertically angled loops, but nothing that couldn't be fixed with a little sanding and a heat gun!

Rotated the "N"logo to make it a "Z" for our "Zorro Nation League" and modified the NFL logo to be the FFL, (Fantasy Football League).

Goes with this trophy in the set: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2083062

Hey, ShoreTrooper, Turn your BlasTech Industries Thermal Detonator into your own personal boombox with this! A modified part of Sean's amazing shoretrooper armor pieces. Pretty sure it wont pass off as 501st approved though.

Modified to accept a 50mm speaker. I've included a newegg link to a pair of speakers which closely resemble the one I have, However I can't guarantee that they will fit.

https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=9SIA27C3GY6611

I've included 2 versions, They are identical except the "KEYED" versions have a 0.3 mm indent for the rim to align during gluing. It could however be an extra hassle. So, decide which one you want to use. Both however, will need to be glued together. Didn't want too much support material getting into small spaces. The "KEYED" rim is also taller by 0.3 mm.

Throw an amp in the tube, Drill a hole for the AUX cord and you're troopin' to the beat!

This is a simple threaded telescope focuser. I suggest you first print with short tube sizes to adjust the eyepieceTolerance and threadTolerance parameters (and maybe threadAngle) for your printer.

I am not sure that I actually want to install it on one of my telescopes--my test print was too rough, but that may be a printer issue. This might be handy if you're building a telescope and need a quick and dirty focuser to put on it for testing.

The scad file uses (and includes built into the scad file, so you don't need to download any dependencies) my Bezier, paths and thread libraries. The Bezier library is used for the flange. The paths library is used to interpolate the Bezier to find how deep to countersink the screws. The thread library is used for the obvious thing.

Update: The adapter for Newtonian tubes had a hole that was too small for the drawtube. This is now fixed.

title: RetroPie Gaming Console for Original N64 Controller

description.text:
This is a case for a Raspberry Pi running RetroPie with a custom controller interface allowing you to use your original N64 controllers from the 90's. The case is dual vented to allow for excessive heat to escape and the fasteners insert from the bottom so that they are not visible from the top. The best use for this system is for playing N64, however there are two USB sockets on the front panel for USB controllers for Super Nintendo, Nintendo, ... etc. Install KODI as a port and use a wireless keyboard to search for shows/movies. Overall, this was a fun project and is super compact and easy to travel with.

Check out how it's made HERE!

-Tile Queues x4, printed at a .3 layer height with 10% infill (Each in a different color)  
-Letter Tiles A and B (x4 each, in four different colors) printed at a .3 layer height with 10% infill  
-Gurus x1 each, (each in a color corresponding to the color of a tile set) printed at a .1 layer height with 10% infill  
-Water x1, printed at a .1 layer height with 10% infill (blue or teal)

description.text:
This is a simple and fast version of a modular organizer. Although an external module are asymmetric, the organizer can be expanded indefinitely, but only in two directions. For example, either into the right and up or into the left and up. (On second image you could see that my organizer grows into the left and up) A drawer's facade is printed separately from a case and then they have to connect by a lock. Drawer partitions also prints separately. This is very handy. The partition can be removed or be preprinted as needed. Besides all parts have thin walls to print faster. There are two types of drawers - with a half height and a full height. Also there are two types of partitions for every kind of drawer (whit four or six cells). There is an inserting section for the half height drawer. Facade's model is universal and can be connected with both versions of drawer.

description.text:
These are part of a research project by MOST (Michigan Tech Open Sustainability Technology Lab) aimed at creating a customizeable pair of glasses that can utilize self-correcting lenses. These lenses allow the user to dial in the correction just by moving a syringe to inject more, or remove the liquid inside the lens. By 3D printing the components the cost of the glasses is reduced significantly and the glasses are able to be customized for the wearer's preferences.
More info on MOST can be found here: http://www.appropedia.org/Category:MOST Note: I need to fix the supports for the hinges. Will get on that soon.

comments.text: Thanks for the comment! They aren't horribly heavy and I think I printed these at 50% fill which was more than enough.  The syringes can be removed if desired and the lenses be plugged.  Depending if you might want to share glasses (think developing world where you might not have glasses for everyone) or if they are just yours.  The lenses I had were passed around and played with by many students and lost some of their fluid which accounts for the air bubbles.  Ideally there wouldn't be any bubbles at all.  Hadn't thought about coloring the lenses though!

You will need:
4 x 608 roller bearings, washers optional-(1)
24 x M8 nuts and washers-(2)
2 x threaded rods, M8 x 13in/330mm
4 x threaded rods, M8 x 8in/200mm

So, how about those Colorfabb 2.2kg spools, eh? Kinda massive, huh? Not too easy to fit onto the side of your printer, ya dig? Almost comically large, y'feel me?
Anyway, this is a rolling cradle for Colorfabb's Hugh Mungus-approved filament spools. We were going to use some 80/20 steel for a frame, but space was an issue and we had these threaded rods left over from a 3D scanner we never got around to building.

  1. The bearings in mine spin pretty freely, but that's because I assembled the rods to be fairly loose. If you'd like something that feels a little more solid, go ahead and add washers to each side of the bearings. However, I'm going to advise you to either sand down the pegs or scale them accordingly for the sake of the spool's width.

  2. Since I was asked about the logistics of creating our own plastic hardware by my higher-ups, I used the chance to make my own spacing washers. I've included them here for you nutty types who want as many parts 3D printed as possible, but I'm not going to tell you they're essential to the design because they're not.

title: 9V Motor Fan Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This set of caps will fit onto the shaft of a 9v motor to turn it into a fan. The fans can be used to push air, of course, but are powerful enough to propel low friction carts across a surface. Several fans mounted onto the same cart serve as a good demonstration of balanced forces.

Designed for these 9v motors: http://a.co/cjTDTPo

Printer:

JellyBOX

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

n/a

Notes:

I printed them in sets of 12 (24 pc.) to reduce babysitting. Each pair will press fit together with enough friction to hold, but at high torque the parts will likely fly apart. For this reason, consider using either a small amount of superglue, or by heat-welding them together with an old soldering iron (see picture).

For the fans in the pictures, I used a piece of common "crafting foam" cut into a rectangle 65mm x 25mm and a small hole in the center. You can do this by hand, or use the attached vector file to cut batches on a laser.
I used Fusion 360 to model the caps based on a design I saw on a cheap hand-held fan.
